Detailed Description

A planet (generation and properties).

Planet Type is defined as follows:

  • Rock : Solid planet without atmosphere (ex: Mercure, Pluto)
  • Ice : Planet mostly covered with water-ice (more than 95%)
  • Water : Planet with atmosphere, and mostly covered with water-ocean (more than 95%)
  • Terrestrial: Planet with atmosphere, and more than 5% of water coverage (ex: Earth)
  • Venusian : Planet with atmosphere, few or no water, and a very high average surface temperature
  • Martian : Planet with atmosphere, few or no water, and a temperate surface temperature (ex: Mars)
  • GasGiant : Regular Gas planet (ex: Jupiter).
  • SubGasGiant: Gas planet with a mass < 20 EM.
  • SubSubGasGiant: Gas planet with a gas part lower than 20% of its total mass (gas dwarf).
  • Asteroids : Solid body with a very small mass.

This function increases the dust mass of the planet (dust, rock, and all solid elements).

mass Dust mass in the planet (unit = solar mass)

This function increases the gas mass of the planet.

Parameters:
mass Gas mass in the planet (unit = solar mass)

long double SG_Planet::calculateAlbedo (  long double  water_fraction,
long double  cloud_fraction,
long double  ice_fraction
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the albedo of the planet.

The Albedo is a mesure of the light and radiation reflected by a planet.

  • Examples : snow=90% ocean=10% planet Earth=30% Moon=12%
  • The cloud adjustment is the fraction of cloud cover obscuring each of the three major components of albedo that lie below the clouds.
    Parameters:
    water_fraction The fraction of the surface covered with oceans [0..1]
    cloud_fraction The fraction of the surface covered with clouds [0..1]
    ice_fraction The fraction of the surface covered with ice [0..1]
    Returns:
    The albedo value is between 0..1 (representing 0%..100%)
    See also:
    calculateSurfaceTemperature

long double SG_Planet::calculateBoilingPoint (  long double  pressure  )  [protected]
 

This function returns the boiling point of water on a planet, under a given atmosphere.

This implements Fogg's equation 21.

Parameters:
pressure The pressure submiitted to the water (Units = millibars). (Use the surface pressure to obtain the boiling temperature on the planet surface).
Returns:
The boiling point (Units = Kelvin)

long double SG_Planet::calculateCloudFraction (  long double  smallest_MW_retained,
long double  hydro_fraction
)  [protected]
 

This function return the fraction of the planet wich is covered with clouds.

Given the surface temperature of a planet (in Kelvin), this function returns the fraction of cloud cover available. This is Fogg's eq.23. See Hart in "Icarus" (vol 33, pp23 - 39, 1978) for an explanation. This equation is Hart's eq.3. Slightly modified by using constants and relationships from Glass's book "Introduction to Planetary Geology", p.46. The 'CLOUD_COVERAGE_FACTOR' is the amount of surface area on Earth covered by one Kg. of cloud.

See also:
calculateSurfaceTemperature

long double SG_Planet::calculateDayLength (   )  [protected]
 

This function calculate the length of the day on the planet.

Fogg's information for this routine came from Dole "Habitable Planets for Man", Blaisdell Publishing Company, NY, 1964. From this, he came up with his eq.12, which is the equation for the 'base_angular_velocity' below. He then used an equation for the change in angular velocity per time (dw/dt) from P. Goldreich and S. Soter's paper "Q in the Solar System" in Icarus, vol 5, pp.375-389 (1966). Using as a comparison the change in angular velocity for the Earth, Fogg has come up with an approximation for our new planet (his eq.13) and take that into account. This is used to find 'change_in_angular_velocity' below.

Used parameters are mass (in solar masses), radius (in Km), orbital period (in days), orbital radius (in AU), density (in g/cc), eccentricity, and whether it is a gas giant or not.

Note: OK when applied on the solar system planets, but wrong (16h) when applied to the Earth. Maybe because the Moon influence is not taken into account.

Returns:
The length of the day (units = hours).

long double SG_Planet::calculateEscapeVelocity (   )  [protected]
 

This function implements the escape velocity calculation.

In a given gravitational field, the escape velocity is the minimum speed an object needs to have to move away indefinitely from the planet, as opposed to falling back or staying in an orbit. Examples: earth=11km/s moon=2km/s sun=617km/s Note that it appears that Fogg's eq.15 is incorrect.

Returns:
The escape velocity of the planet (unit = cm/sec).

The mass is in units of solar mass.

The radius is in kilometers.

long double SG_Planet::calculateExoTemperature (   )  [protected]
 

This function returns the exospheric temperature of the planet.

The exosphere is the outermost, least dense portion of the atmosphere. In this area, the gas molecule velocity increase (especially H and He), and the molecules may escape from the atmosphere. For this reason, the temperature also increase in the exosphere. For the Earth, the exospheric temperature is about 1000 C.

Returns:
The exospheric temperature of the planet (unit = Kelvin).

bool SG_Planet::calculateFaceLocking (   )  [protected]
 

This function determine if the same side of the planet is always facing the star.

Returns:
TRUE if a face of the planet is locked toward the star.

void SG_Planet::calculateGasPlanet (   )  [protected]
 

Calculations for a gas planet.

Note that the calculation function must be called in this order, because they are using values calculated by the calls of previous functions.

  • Gas planet have no accessible surface, or no surface at all.
  • We call 'surface temperature' the temperature at 1 bar.
  • (Jupiter=165K - Saturn=135K - Neptune=75K - Uranus=70K)
  • We call 'radius' the limit where the gas pressure is 0.1 bar.

void SG_Planet::calculateGlobalClimate (   )  [protected]
 

This function calculates all the climatic conditions on the planet.

This function calls calculateSurfaceClimate until converging to 1/4 degree.

See also:
calculateSolidPlanet calculateSurfaceClimate

long double SG_Planet::calculateGravity (  long double  distance  )  [protected]
 

This function calculates the gravity of a planet.

Parameters:
distance The distance from the planet center, where the gravity is calculated. (units = km) (use mRadius to obtain the surface gravity).
Returns:
The gravity (Units = Earth gravities)

Acceleration (units = cm/sec2)

long double SG_Planet::calculateGreehouseRiseTemp (  long double  optical_depth,
long double  effective_temp
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the rise in temperature produced by the greenhouse effect.

The Greenhouse effect is the warming trend on the surface, and on the lower atmosphere of a planet, that occcurs when solar radiation is trapped, as emissions from the planet. Like in a greehouse, the atmosphere may keep the solar radiation, and rise the surface temperature.

  • This is Fogg's eq.20, and is also Hart's eq.20 in his "Evolution of Earth's Atmosphere" article.
  • Note: pow(x,0.25) was changed to pow(x,0.4) to match Venus.
  • Examples: Earth = +30 Venus = +500

Returns:
The temperature rise, due to the GreeHouse effect (units = Kelvin).

bool SG_Planet::calculateGreenhouseEffect (   )  [protected]
 

This function determine if the planet suffers from the Greenhouse effect.

The new definition is based on the inital surface temperature and what state water is in. If it's too hot, the water will never condense out of the atmosphere, rain down and form an ocean. The albedo used here was chosen so that the boundary is about the same as the old method Neither zone, nor r_greenhouse are used in this version Note: If the orbital radius of the planet is too big, 99% of it's volatiles are assumed to have been deposited in surface reservoirs, (otherwise, it suffers from the greenhouse effect).

long double SG_Planet::calculateHydroFraction (  long double  volatile_gas_inventory  )  [protected]
 

This function calculates the fraction of the planet which is covered with water.

This function is Fogg's eq.22. Given the volatile gas inventory and planetary radius of a planet (in Km), this function returns the fraction of the planet covered with water. Note: the fraction of Earth's surface covered by water is 71%, not 75% as Fogg used.

See also:
calculateSurfaceTemperature

long double SG_Planet::calculateIceFraction (  long double  hydro_fraction  )  [protected]
 

This function returns the fraction of the planet wich is covered with ice.

Given the surface temperature of a planet (in Kelvin), this function returns the fraction of the planet's surface covered by ice.

  • This is Fogg's eq.24. See Hart[24] in Icarus vol.33, p.28 for an explanation.
  • Modify constant from 70 to 90 in order to bring it more in line with the fraction of the Earth's surface covered with ice, which is approximatly 1.6%.
    See also:
    calculateSurfaceTemperature

long double SG_Planet::calculateOpacity (  long double  molecular_weight,
long double  pressure
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the optical depth of the atmosphere.

The optical depth increase when the atmosphere is composed with light elements and when the atmosphere is thin (low pressure). The optical depth is useful in determining the amount of greenhouse effect on a planet.

Parameters:
molecular_weight The atmosphere melecule weight (unit = gram)
pressure The atmosphere pressure at the surface of the planet (unit=mB)
Returns:
The Optical Depth (unitless)

Returns:
the orbit period of the planet (unit = Earth days)

long double SG_Planet::calculatePressure (  long double  radius  )  [protected]
 

This function determine the pressure on the planet.

This implements Fogg's equation 18. It use the 'inventory' of the atmosphere (reference value = 1000). This is more dedicated for solid (non gas) planets.

Parameters:
radius The distance from the planet center where the pressure is calculated. (unit=km) (use mRadius to get the planet surface pressure).
Returns:
The pressure (Units = millibars)

long double SG_Planet::calculateVolatilGasRatio (  long double  escape_vel,
long double  stellar_mass,
bool  greenhouse_effect,
bool  accreted_gas
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the 'inventory' of the gas in the atmosphere.

This function implements Fogg's equation 17. The Earth inventory is 1000 (reference).

Parameters:

stellar_mass The mass of the star (unit=solar mass)
greenhouse_effect TRUE if the planet is under a greenhouse effect.
accreted_gas TRUE if the planet has a certain amount of gas.
Returns:
The inventory (unitless).

Returns:
The 'empirical' density (Units = grams/cc) /*--------------------------------------------------------------------------

long double SG_Planet::estimateMinimalMoleculeWeight (   )  [protected]
 

This function returns an estimation of the smallest molecular weight retained by the planet.

This is an approximate value (molecule_limit), which is useful for determining the atmosphere composition. This function is based on the 'cinetic gas theory'.

  • PV = nRT (perfect gas equation)
  • E = mv/2 (cinetic energy)
  • RT = mv/3
    Returns:
    The minimal molecule weight retained by the planet gravity. (unit=gram)
    See also:
    calculateMinimalMoleculeWeight

long double SG_Planet::getGasLife (  long double  molecular_weight  )  [protected]
 

This function calculates the time it takes for 1/e of a gas to escape from a planet's atmosphere.

Taken from Dole p.34. He cites Jeans (1916) & Jones (1923)

Parameters:
molecular_weight 
Returns:
Gas life time (unit = years)

long double SG_Planet::getKothariRadius (  long double  mass,
bool  giant,
int  zone
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the radius of the core of the planet (units = km).

This formula is listed as eq.9 in Fogg's article, although some typos crop up in that eq. See "The Internal Constitution of Planets", by Dr. D. S. Kothari, Mon. Not. of the Royal Astronomical Society, vol 96 pp.833-843, 1936 for the derivation. Specifically, this is Kothari's eq.23, which appears on page 840.

int SG_Planet::getOrbitalZone (  long double  luminosity,
long double  orbit_radius
)  [protected]
 

This function returns the orbital zone of the planet.

Zone 1: Zone near of the sun, luminous and warm (ie: Earth). Zone 2: Medium zone. Zone 3: Zone far from the sun. The sun looks like a star from there.

Parameters:
luminosity The lumionosity of the sun (ie: the primary star).
orbit_radius The radius of the orbit of the planet (units = UA)
Returns:
The 'orbital zone' of the planet (1-2-3).

long double SG_Planet::getRMSvelocity (  long double  molecular_weight  )  [protected]
 

This function returns the RMS velocity of a certain gas, under the planet high atmosphere temperature.

This is Fogg's eq.16. The molecular weight is used as the basis of the Root Mean Square (RMS) velocity of the molecule or atom.

Parameters:
molecular_weight The molecular weight of the gas (unit=gram)
Returns:
The RMS velocity of the gas molecules (unit=cm/sec)

void SG_Planet::setPlanetNumber (  int  number  ) 
 

This function changes the number of the planet.

At the begining of the process, the number is the creation order of the planets, but during the sorting process, the number is set to the orbital order of the planet.

Parameters:
number The number is in the range [0..N]
